node.title: Man who fatally beat, dragged wife 70 metres along Darwin's Mindil Beach pleads guilty
node.alt: A photo of Mindil Beach during the daytime.
node.description: The NT Supreme Court hears the man, who pleaded guilty to reckless manslaughter, dragged his wife into shallow water on the popular Darwin beach before running to higher ground and claiming to witnesses that she'd drowned
node.content:
["WARNING: This article contains content that some readers may find distressing.", "A 38-year-old man who beat, stabbed and strangled his wife before dragging her 70 metres along one of the Northern Territory's most popular beaches and dumping her unconscious body into the sea has pleaded guilty to reckless manslaughter causing her death.", "Darwin's Supreme Court on Monday heard details of how Garsek Nawirridj, of Gunbalayna in western Arnhem Land, caused his wife's death on Christmas Eve in 2019.", "Crown prosecutor Tami Grealy said Nawirridj had brutally assaulted his wife (whose\u00a0family have requested her name be withheld) at an itinerant camp near Mindil Beach in Darwin, including by strangling her with her own dress.", "\"Investigators subsequently found bloodstained sand and two empty chardonnay bottles at this location, one of which had DNA with a profile consistent (of the victim) and a palm print matching that of the offender,\" Ms Grealy said.", "\"At some point, (she) lost consciousness due to the blunt force trauma to the head sustained during the assaults. The offender dragged (her) from the camp spot along the beach, approximately 70 metres, in the direction of Bullocky Point.\"", "", "
The court heard Nawirridj\u00a0had exhibited\u00a0threatening behaviour, including setting his wife\u2019s car alight, before\u00a0the fatal assault.(ABC News: Al Dowler)
", "In the middle of Mindil Beach, the court heard agreed facts that\u00a0Nawirridj dragged his wife into shallow water, before running to higher ground and claiming to witnesses that she'd drowned and to alert the police.", "Emergency services were called to the scene and managed to recover a light pulse from the victim. She was transferred to Royal Darwin Hospital but died\u00a0at 12:30am on Christmas Eve.", "The court heard Nawirridj lied to investigating police officers, telling them he and his partner had been assaulted by others, and continued his false claims\u00a0that his wife had drowned.", "\"During the course of the resuscitation efforts by first responders at the beach, the offender stayed nearby, repeatedly wailing and crying out things like, 'Don't take her away, it's Christmas,'\" Ms Grealy said.", "In the days leading up to the fatal assault, the court heard, Nawirridj's behaviour had become increasingly threatening, including setting his wife's car alight in the Darwin suburb of Fannie Bay.", "He also threatened to burn down a Fannie Bay petrol station, holding a lighter up to a petrol pump nozzle and yelling at witnesses: \"I will light this thing and you will all die\".", "Despite these incidents, the court heard police did not keep him in custody before the fatal attack on his wife.", "Nawirridj's case returns to court for further sentencing submissions on December 9."]
